"The reason we have mass unemployment isn’t that we spent too much in the past but that we’re spending too little now, and that this problem can and should be solved."

Attention should be paid to a third reason - more goods and services can be produced with less employment. If we try to jack up the output to the level that provides jobs for everyone who wants one, where will we put all that stuff, let alone how do we pay for it?

The makers would be hard working white and rural while the takers would be urban and primarily of color. Gas company propaganda.

U.S. emissions are down for a great many reasons, not the least of which is that we've exported much of our manufacturing to places like China that don't have any environmental regulations. We also burn less gasoline since the recession started, and we've become somewhat more energy-efficient.

Natural gas plays a role in emissions reduction, but is is only less polluting than coal if upstream methane leaks are kept below 2.5–3%. In some gas wells in the west, the leaks are around 9%. Leaks throughout the entire gas delivery system have yet to be evaluated — in part because the gas companies refuse to divulge their information — but the chances of overall leakage being below 4% are very slim when you consider the huge number of ancient, funky delivery pipes in our cities.

Also natural gas isn't particularly cheap, and the market is volatile since most plays play out rather quickly. Some electric companies are already reinstalling the coal burning equipment they dumped when they converted to gas a couple of years ago.

Along with the permanent damage caused by fracking and greenhouse emissions, gas it problematic because it is the opposite of a bridge fuel — investment in gas extraction and infrastructure is a roadblock to the development of renewables.

This is a fine analysis by the person I think is the
leader of this debate. In my own blog, I dismissed
this speech as more of the same from the Treasury.

Another speech to be read, by another leader of the
debate, Tom Hoenig, can be found in its draft form
on the FDIC website. However, my notes show him
estimating the capital ratio of the TBTFs at 3.5% and
criticizing the regulators for lacking well structured
examination procedures that can supervise bank
capital.

My thesis is that these banks should have been seized
thirty years ago, that they are chronically insolvent, as
has been found by an IMF paper written by a group
that included Prof. Johnson, and that Treasury's
policy continues to be the promotion of the growth of
highly leveraged zombie banks in the name of serving
US multinationals and gaining share from even more
troubled eurozombs.

I've been using the figure of $15t to represent the size
of embedded losses the othorities are hiding and moving
around to hide the true condition of the TBTF as the
bailout proceeds apace through a variety of programs
and the carry trade. However, at the same Levy Institute
conference where Miller delivered her speech, a study
was distributed entitled "The Lender of Last Resort: A
Critical Analysis of the Federal Reserve's Unprecedented
Intervention After 2007" that uses a number of $29t that
we might as well round up to $30t.

So the bottom line is that nothing has ever been done to
contain the growth of zombie banks.

That's an issue that deserves to be treated properly in response to another piece, possibly even by Mr. Egan, because this may not be the last time we need to consider it.

To Peter Quennell:

Any prosecutor who was honestly convinced that the first appeal would have reversed a lower court finding of guilt yet still brought the case deserves to be cashiered and kept thereafter quite far indeed from any post where his decisions really affect lives.

And I don't know whether the girl is guilty or innocent; but what I do know is that the vast majority of lawyers and judges here, not merely "dozens", believe that this action should never have gone to court in Italy based on a complete lack of evidence to support the charge. When cops and judges are allowed this kind of latitude to determine actions based on mere suspicion, you'd better hide your wallet -- and head for the hills.

Peter Quennel: Please read the column. " those [finger] prints, that blood and much more physical evidence lined up exactly with a man, Rudy Guede, who had fled to Germany shortly after the murder, the police had their culprit. Guede was later convicted".,

Contrast that with NYC's police budget of $4.2 billion, of which it dedicates $340 million for anti-terror preparedness. NYC's 35,000-strong PD could have handled this alone; and done an extremely good job of it. Kudos to Mike Bloomberg.

The Italians. There's reason in your argument, from our perspective. The evidence against Ms. Knox may never have resulted in a trial here; and if it had, it almost certainly would have been dismissed as insufficient to sustain the charge.

So a girl, probably innocent but not, in any event, provably guilty, rotted for a time in prison. Bad judges, bad cops.

It has become fashionable to distort the original meaning of the word "entitlement", giving it a negative connotation. In fact, the original meaning of entitlement,  where Social Security and Medicare were concerned, was of benefits that were fully earned by making payments into a fund over a lifetime. There should be absolutely nothing derogatory about the word in this sense. The right wing word slander machine lumps earned entitlements in with other programs designed to promote the general welfare of society, such as food stamps, disability payments, and low income cash and housing assistance. The implied guilt trip is a complete injustice both to those who receive benefits they rightly deserve because they paid for them, and to those who through no fault of their own are recipients of a helping hand by society through the vehicle of government assistance just at the time when they most need it. The question the rest of us need to ask is, since when did it become a bad idea to be a good Samaritan in the first place, and why is the right wing peddling the trashing of the only form of savings many workers have to face old age with?

"Dear Professor Krugman: please pay attention in class."
Dear Mr. Terry: please pay attention to your tone, as it serves only to embarrass you. You may have written the single worst opening line that I have ever seen in a popular comment. Your condescension is misplaced, to put it kindly. Perhaps you have interesting things to say, but I couldn't get past the bad taste left in my mouth by that ridiculous pomposity. Charmed, I'm sure.

Dear Professor Krugman: please pay attention in class. There are things to learn there.

"Does a continuing depression actually serve the interests of the wealthy?"

While you posit your doubts, recessions have manifold benefits for the wealthy, employer class.

1. Fewer new start up companies to bother their established ones. Less competition on price, the sole reason many enterprises use as their reason for being. Less competition means higher profits.

2. Recessions drive the weak competitors out of business. Again, less competition on price as the weak ones fall. The potential for near monopoly power in some sectors rises. This is the goal of all corporations, to control prices and the market.

3. Lower and less strident demands on wages and benefits from employees.

4. An abundance of available workers, especially those so anxious to take a job that they will work for far less.

5. Less job shifting by workers. Lower costs on training/hiring.

6. More exclusivity in the places the rich go and the things they buy. Fewer tourists in St. Barts.

7.Lower prices for the 4th, 5th, 6th and 7th house.

8. More power for the rich as those below them lose money and power.

America's corporations are not America's any more. They are citizens, beasts, of the world, roaming the planet, taking what they like, shifting dollars and tax burdens around in a giant whirl, supporting life styles for those at the top that would make ancient kings blush.
